text: Night settles in. The snow outside whispers like fine sand, and the hearth burns brightly, the wood occasionally cracking with a soft pop.

I lean against the counter, the dim yellow light illuminating half the inn. Lucia has long since gone upstairs to sleep. The entire place is so quiet that I can hear the wind breathing through the cracks in the door.
The firelight flickers, and the shadow on the wall sways twice. I think it’s the wind—until the stairs creak softly.
Alicia descends wrapped in her silver-white cloak, her hair faintly golden in the firelight. She approaches the counter and gestures toward the rack. “Still awake? Good—pour me a drink.”
“Can’t sleep?”
“Mm.” She answers softly. “The nights in this town are too quiet. So quiet they remind me of… somewhere else.”
I pour her a drink. She sits at the counter, her movements so light they’re almost soundless. The amber liquid glows softly in the firelight.
She doesn’t drink immediately, only gazes at the surface of the glass in thought.
“Your wine is unusual,” she says with a faint smile. “Not like the warmed wine we have in the south.”
“People here are afraid of the cold creeping in too fast. Stronger liquor helps keep them warm.”
“True.” She takes a sip. “The winters of the North… they can freeze a person’s dreams solid.”
“That doesn’t sound like something a traveler would say.”
“Maybe I’m not.” She looks at me. “I came here to investigate something.”
“Something serious?”
“Perhaps it’s life.” She meets my gaze, firelight reflected in her gray-blue eyes, deep as a lake beneath snow.
“Or rather—fate.” The air tightens as she adds.
“Do you believe in fate?”
“Fate? I think it’s just an excuse people make for themselves.”
She laughs softly. “That does sound like something someone who’s seen through everything would say.”
“I wouldn’t say that. I just think fate is too easily used as a way to avoid responsibility.”
“Perhaps.” She murmurs. “But some people never had a choice from the day they were born.”
I don’t fully understand, only that her tone grows heavy.
“And you? Are you one of those people who ‘never had a choice’?”
Her hand pauses at the rim of her cup, as if she wants to answer—but stops herself.
“I don’t remember.”
“You don’t remember?”
“That’s right.” She smiles faintly. “I always feel like I’ve lived through nights like this many times—fire, wine, snow, and… many kind or unkind faces.”
My heart skips. “What do you mean?”
She blinks. “Nothing. When you’ve seen enough, you get sentimental now and then.”
The hearth cracks sharply, and her shadow stretches across the wall. Not one shadow—but two. One sits before me; the other is faint, slightly blurred.
I blink, and they merge into one again.
“Did you know a soul can leave traces?”
“What do you mean?”
She looks into the fire. “Some people, three days after death, have shadows that follow their traces back to three days earlier.”
“It’s an ancient magic—Soul Mechanics. It lets the dead return to the world three days prior, to rewrite fate.”
“Sounds like a story.”
“It is. Sometimes stories are safer than truth.”
Her glass is empty, yet she still grips its rim.
“If you had the chance to relive three days,” she suddenly asks, “what would you do?”

options.text: Option A: Say seriously, “I would try to change fate.” 【Intelligence Check (DC 7)】
Option B: Casually say, “I’d keep running the inn and go on with my life.” 【charisma Check (DC 5)】
Option C: Ask her in return, “What about you? What would you want to change?” 【Charisma Check (DC 6)】
